file_name: virtuososurgicalinc_20191227_1-a_ex1a-6 mat ctrct_11933379_ex1a-6 mat ctrct_license agreement.pdf

perturbation.original_text:
4.5
Late Payments: In the event that any payment due hereunder is not made when due, the payment shall accrue interest beginning
on the tenth day following the due date thereof, calculated at the annual rate of six percent (6%), the interest being compounded
on the last day of each calendar year. Each such royalty payment when made shall be accompanied by all interest so accrued.
Said interest and the payment and acceptance thereof shall not negate or waive the right of JHU to seek any other remedy, legal
or equitable, to which it may be entitled because of the delinquency of any payment.
perturbation.changed_text:
4.5
Late Payments: In the event that any payment due hereunder is not made when due, the payment shall accrue interest beginning on the first day following the due date thereof, calculated at the annual rate of twenty-five percent (25%), the interest being compounded daily. Each such royalty payment when made shall be accompanied by all interest so accrued. Said interest and the payment and acceptance thereof shall not negate or waive the right of JHU to seek any other remedy, legal or equitable, to which it may be entitled because of the delinquency of any payment.
perturbation.explanation: The modified text changes the late payment terms to accrue interest from the first day following the due date at an annual rate of 25%, compounded daily. This conflicts with usury laws in many states, including Maryland, which may limit the maximum interest rate that can be charged. Charging interest from the first day also contradicts standard business practice and could be deemed unreasonable.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Maryland Usury Law (potentially), general principles of contract law regarding unconscionability.

perturbation.original_text:
6.2
Termination by Company: Company may terminate this Agreement and the license granted herein, for any reason, upon giving
JHU sixty (60) days written notice under Paragraph 8.1.
perturbation.changed_text:
6.2
Termination by Company: Company may terminate this Agreement and the license granted herein, for any reason, upon giving JHU ten (10) days written notice under Paragraph 8.1.
perturbation.explanation: The original text requires a 60-day written notice for termination by the Company. The modified text reduces this to 10 days. This could be problematic under contract law principles of reasonable notice, especially considering the complexity of the agreement and the potential impact on JHU. Courts may find a 10-day notice period to be insufficient and thus unenforceable, particularly if JHU needs a longer time to find a new licensee or address potential market disruptions. Furthermore, under common law a 30-day notice is considered the minimum when terminating a contract.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Common Law - Reasonable Notice for Contract Termination

perturbation.original_text:
4.6
Records: The Company shall make and retain, for a period of three (3) years following the period of each report required by
Paragraph 4.4, true and accurate records, files and books of account containing all the data reasonably required for the full
computation and verification of sales and other information required in Paragraph 4.4. Such books and records shall be in
accordance with generally accepted accounting principles consistently applied. The Company shall permit the inspection and
copying of such records, files and books of account by JHU or its agents during regular business hours upon ten (10) business
days’ written notice to the Company. Such inspection shall not be made more than once each calendar year. All costs of such
inspection and copying shall be paid by JHU, provided that if any such inspection shall reveal that an error has been made in the
amount equal to five percent (5%) or more of such payment, such costs shall be borne by the Company.
perturbation.changed_text:
4.6
Records: The Company shall make and retain, for a period of one (1) year following the period of each report required by Paragraph 4.4, true and accurate records, files and books of account containing all the data reasonably required for the full computation and verification of sales and other information required in Paragraph 4.4. Such books and records shall be in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles consistently applied. The Company shall permit the inspection and copying of such records, files and books of account by JHU or its agents during regular business hours upon twenty (20) business days’ written notice to the Company. Such inspection shall not be made more than once every five calendar years. All costs of such inspection and copying shall be paid by JHU, provided that if any such inspection shall reveal that an error has been made in the amount equal to twenty percent (20%) or more of such payment, such costs shall be borne by the Company.
perturbation.explanation: The original text requires the Company to retain records for three years. The modification reduces this to one year. According to the IRS and general accounting best practices, businesses should retain financial records for at least three years. Also, this reduces JHU's ability to discover discrepancies, and by increasing the threshold for error before costs are borne by the company and limiting the inspection frequency the contract fails to protect their financials.
perturbation.contradicted_law: IRS Guidelines on Record Retention, General accepted accounting principles
